definition:
A real sequence $(x_n)$ is said to be **almost convergent** to $L$ if
each Banach limit assigns the same value $L$ to the sequence $(x_n)$.

Lorentz [@lorentz] proved that $(x_n)$ is almost convergent to $L$ if
and only if
$$\lim\limits_{p\to\infty} \frac{x_{n}+\ldots+x_{n+p-1}}p=L$$ uniformly
in $n$.

The above limit can be rewritten in detail as
$$(\forall \varepsilon>0) (\exists p_0) (\forall p>p_0) (\forall n) \left|\frac{x_{n}+\ldots+x_{n+p-1}}p-L\right|<\varepsilon.$$

Almost convergence is studied in summability theory. It is an example of
a summability method which cannot be represented as a matrix method.

[9]{} G. Bennett and N.J. Kalton: [Consistency theorems for almost
convergence.]{} *Trans. Amer. Math. Soc.*, 198:23–43, 1974.
